results.title: Mallee blossom
results.brief_description: This is Maureen Barry’s story of her life as a farmer, wife, mother and rural nurse in the dusty bowl of the Mallee in outback Victoria. She tells of the hardships and isolation, but also of the gradual blossoming of the land as both she and her husband keep pace with technology, embracing sustainable farming practices so as to leave the land in a better state for those who follow. This story is part of a project funded by VicHealth and partnership with the women’s rural network, Partners in Grain.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: All change please
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
“All change please. That’s what they say when the train is at the last station.” Diana Anderson began her journey around 23 years ago when she moved on to her husband’s family farm in north-west Victoria. Worked on for generations, Diana and Choco improved and changed the farming business, raising their two boys and enjoying the life for almost 23 years. That is until they were confronted with the distressing news the family partnership was to be sold. For Diana this was the end of one journey and the start of another - a new beginning.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: Kylie
results.brief_description: A story about family relationships and two sisters growing up without a father. Separated by distance, emotionally and physically, Scarlett expresses her thoughts and feelings about her older sister Kylie. Change, it seems, is inevitable but change can also inspire.

group.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]

results.title: The Art of rhyme
results.brief_description:
Ever since a child Mykel has had a fascination for the art of rhyme and a respect for the artistic and creative use of the english language. In this animated piece, he speaks of his dedication to perfecting his art through rap and hip-hop where constant rhyme is no longer a restriction and each syllable and phrase flows into a harmonious melody. “Allowing your mind to be blown away, storming the front of your imagination and pushing it to the limit - that’s the buzz!”
Music by Pabstrakt.

group.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]

results.title: Laughter and hope
results.brief_description: In 1966 at the age of nine Maria Savarino was reunited with her parents who had migrated to Australia from Italy six years earlier. In doing so she also lost a very special person - her Aunt Maria, who had looked after her in those intervening years in Italy. This is Maria’s story about her very special namesake and role model.

group.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]

results.title: Indelible impressions
results.brief_description: A family of women – they share pride and a passion for life; a love for dancing, talking and eating and each woman has left an indelible impression on those of the next generation. In this story Jade shares her memories and thoughts with the newest and youngest member in the family, her niece, and poses the question, “Will the women of our family leave an indelible mark on you just as they did on me?”

group.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]

results.title: Just like dad
results.brief_description: Gemma’s dad, an old rocker from way back, is passionate about music and anything and everything that is remotely connected to music. This addiction comes to a head when dad discovers Ebay on the home computer. Searches and purchases; Ebay has taken over his life. Worse still, Ebay the enemy is now growing on Gemma. She is her father’s daughter! Uses stills and animation.

group.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]

results.title: La partria o la tumba
results.brief_description: Socialist parents, rebellious children - it runs in the blood. Esteban’s parents originally came from Uruguay but were forced to flee to Australia in 1974 from the ruling military regime. His father, aged 32, and mother, aged 21, eventually settled in Melbourne raising four children and establishing the first South American bakery, in Yarraville. In this story, Esteban talks of his family’s experiences and his deep respect for his wonderful rebellious parents.

group.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]

results.title: Patience
results.brief_description: A poetic tale of elusive love, of numbness and loss and being shut off from the outside world. Can love be found? An evocative work created through the use of black and white images and an ambient soundtrack.

group.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]

results.title: The Way I see things
results.brief_description: Ashleigh’s older step-brother has always been there for her. Growing up without a father she turned to her step-brother, learning from his experiences and cherishing the close bond that had formed between them - a bond that Ashleigh is determined to keep.
